description:
Fusarium keratoplasticum is a species of filamentous fungus that belongs to the genus Fusarium. It is primarily known for its ability to cause keratoplasty, a type of fungal infection of the cornea of the eye.

Fusarium keratoplasticum is a member of the Fusarium solani species complex, which is a group of closely related Fusarium species that are often associated with human and plant diseases. The fungus is typically found in soil, decaying plant material, and other environmental sources.

The defining features of Fusarium keratoplasticum include its production of septate, hyaline (colorless) hyphae, and its ability to form characteristic, sickle-shaped macroconidia (spores) with distinct foot cells. The fungus can also produce microconidia (smaller spores) and chlamydospores (thick-walled, resting spores) under certain conditions.

Fusarium keratoplasticum is an opportunistic pathogen that can infect the cornea, often following traumatic eye injuries or contact lens wear. The infection can lead to corneal ulceration, scarring, and potentially vision loss if left untreated. Proper diagnosis and prompt antifungal treatment are crucial for managing Fusarium keratoplasticum infections.
